publicwhip.major-heading: Preamble

speech.p: The House met at a Quarter before Three of the Clock, Mr. SPEAKER in the Chair.

publicwhip.major-heading: PRIVATE BUSINESS.

speech.p: Wessex Electricity Bill (King's Consent signified).
Bill read the Third time, and passed.

publicwhip.major-heading: Oral Answers to Questions — HOLIDAYS (SCOTLAND).

speech.p: asked the Minister of Labour what is to be the position of the Glasgow Fair holidays this year; and whether it is intended to introduce a spread-over system?
asked the Minister of Labour whether he has any statement to make regarding the spread-over of holidays in Scotland?

speech.speakername: The Minister of Labour (Mr. Ernest Brown)
speech.p: I have no special information regarding the Glasgow Fair holidays. The method of arranging holidays is a matter for settlement in the light of local and industrial circumstances, and I have no intention of trying to regulate it in any stereotyped manner by central instructions.
Is the Minister prepared to use his influence to see that regular holidays are continued while war is on and that it will not always be a case of work, work, work?
The hon. Member may be sure that the experience of the last war will be fully borne in mind.
In any spread-out arrangement will the right hon. Gentleman see that there is a spread in connection with school holidays and take that into account, so as to secure uniformity?

That was one of the points that the committee which discussed this
matter had fully in mind. The position in Lancashire and Scotland has always been different from that which normally operates in England.
On the occasion of the last Glasgow Fair, were there not so many people on the Central Station that they could not get away?
I am sure they enjoyed themselves.

publicwhip.major-heading: Oral Answers to Questions — UNEMPLOYMENT.

speech.p: asked the Minister of Labour how many shipbuilding and ship-repairing workers, distinguishing between skilled and unskilled, were registered as unemployed at South Shields on the latest date for which statistics are available?

The available figures relate to wholly unemployed men aged 18 years and over. At 12th February, 1940, there were 107 wholly unemployed men registered at the South Shields Employment Exchange as applicants for work in shipbuilding and ship-repairing occupations. It is not possible to give separate figures for skilled shipyard workers, but the total of 107 includes 62 men registered in shipyard labouring occupations.
Is the right hon. Gentleman doing anything to assist the First Lord of the Admiralty to absorb these men?
We are doing everything we can, but there are certain difficulties, especially with regard to those who were skilled at hand-rivetting and may be elderly men.

asked the Minister of Labour how many men over 18 years of age are now unemployed in South Shields; what were the corresponding figures six and 12 months before, respectively; and how many of the men now unemployed have been unemployed for a consecutive period of more than six months?

At 12th February, 1940, there were 6,300 unemployed men, aged 18 and over, on the registers of the South Shields Employment Exchange, as compared with 6,430 at 14th August, 1939, and 8,772 at 13th February, 1939. The 6,300 men on the registers at 12th
February, included 6,090 applicants for insurance benefit or unemployment allowances, of whom 1,436 had been continuously on the registers for six months or more as compared with over 2,600 in the previous February and August. Corresponding figures are not available in respect of persons not applying for benefit or allowances.
Will the right hon. Gentleman take some steps to enable these men to take the part they are anxious to take in winning the war?

The hon. Member will see that there has been a very rapid improvement, and I have no doubt that in the months ahead there will be a still more rapid improvement, but the position in that area is one of the most difficult in the whole of the last 10 years.
How many of those who have been out of work for six months are miners?
I could not say without notice.

asked the Minister of Labour to what industries chiefly do the 1,194 unemployed persons categoried as belonging to all other industries and services, out of a total of 3,473 unemployed in the Greenock area on 12th February, 1940, belong; how are they distributed among these industries; and what percentage unemployed do they represent in each case?
I am having these figures extracted and will forward them to the hon. and learned Member as soon as possible.

asked the Minister of Labour whether reasonable preference is being given, where practicable, to people resident in the North Staffordshire area, who are unemployed and who desire to be employed on contracts being carried out for the Government?

The general practice in selecting applicants to fill vacancies notified to Employment Exchanges is to give preference to suitable unemployed applicants living in the area where the work is situated or within daily travelling distance. I have no doubt that this practice is being followed in the North Staffordshire area.

asked the Minister of Labour the number of registered unemployed in the Employment Exchange districts of Dewsbury and Batley, respectively, on the 1st March, 1939 and 1940, distinguishing between the number of men and women, respectively?
As the reply includes a table of figures, I will, if I may, circulate it in the OFFICIAL REPORT.
Following is the reply:

Figures for 1st March are not available. The table below shows the numbers of unemployed men and women, aged 18 years and over, on the registers of the Dewsbury and Batley Employment Exchanges at 13th February, 1939, and 12th February, 1940:

asked the Minister of Labour whether it is intended to discontinue the work of the Commissioner for the Special Areas; and, if so, when and whether it is intended to make provision for the continuation of the social services, and particularly, the erection and support of nursery schools in these areas when the present arrangement terminates?

I have nothing to add to the statement I made on 12th December, 1939, when moving an Amendment to the Expiring Laws (Continuance) Bill to provide for continuation of the Special Areas Acts. In the circumstances the last part of the Question does not arise.
Will the assistance promised to the Save the Children Fund to provide nursery schools in the distressed areas now be implemented?
I will send the hon. Member the passage from my speech, and perhaps he will communicate with me on particular points of that kind.
asked the Minister of Labour the total number of registered unemployed in Scotland up to the latest available date?
At 12th February, 1940, there were 184,269 unemployed persons on the registers of Employment Exchanges in Scotland.

In view of that high figure and the large number of Scottish people away in the Forces or on war work, does the Minister intend to make a survey of the whole position in Scotland in order to bring in some particular scheme?

I do not think there is any necessity for that, because we are well aware of the position in each area, and I have no doubt there will be as great an improvement as there has been since last year. On 12th February, 1939, the figure was 268,000.
Does not the right hon. Gentleman think that the figure is excessively high, in view of the numbers away and those on war work?
It is too high, and I shall be glad to see it lowered.

While admitting that unemployment in Scotland has been reduced, is it not a terrible thing for the Government to admit that there are over 100,000 unemployed in Scotland? What are the Government prepared to do to alter that state of affairs?
If the hon. Member will look at the next figures, he may find that they are better.

asked the Minister of Labour whether he is aware that many young men are being kept from getting work by the prospect of being called up, but that in many cases such an event is months ahead; and will he take steps usefully to employ them in the meantime?

I am aware that some young men find difficulty in obtaining employment while awaiting enlistment in the Forces, but my information does not lead me to suppose that any considerable number are affected in this way. Special arrangements are in operation to enable any unemployed man who has registered for military service to be called up as early as possible if he so desires. Men liable for service who have not yet registered, and who are not covered by the Schedule of Reserved Occupations, can, of course, volunteer for immediate enlistment.
If I bring some cases to the attention of the right hon. Gentleman, is it possible for him to deal with them?
I shall be glad to look into them and discuss the matter with my hon. Friend.

Is the right hon. Gentleman aware that there are young men who were registered for the Navy as long ago as October last who are still hanging about and becoming more and more demoralised because they have not been called up?
There is always a difficulty, of course, in doing our best to meet the desires of men to join one particular Service and calling them up.

asked the Minister of Labour whether he has yet received the reports of the Unemployment Insurance
Statutory Committee on the financial condition of the Unemployment Fund for the past year; and what action he proposes to take with regard to the committee's recommendations?

I have received the reports in question. The Government have decided to accept the committee's recommendations, and the necessary draft order will shortly be laid before Parliament for approval. Copies of the reports will be available later to-day.
asked the Minister of Labour whether, in view of rising prices, he will extend the period of operation of the winter allowances made by the Unemployment Assistance Board?
No, Sir. I would refer the hon. Member to my reply to his Question of 7th March.
Does not the right hon. Gentleman think, in view of the times we live in, that this suggestion is worthy of consideration?
I will call the attention of the Board to the remarks of the hon. Member.
In view of the exceptional severity of this winter, could not the date on which this allowance ends be extended?
That is a matter for the Board to consider. I will call the attention of the Board to the hon. Member's suggestion.

asked the Minister of Labour the total number of unemployed men, women and young persons, respectively, in the county of Durham at the latest convenient date, together with the respective totals for coalmining and shipyard workers?
I will have the available figures extracted and will forward them to the hon. Member as soon as possible.
Can the Minister say whether those figures are large or small, and when he anticipates that those persons will be engaged in useful industry?
I have not got the figures yet.

publicwhip.major-heading: Oral Answers to Questions — WAR INDUSTRIES (EMPLOYMENT OF WOMEN).

speech.p: asked the Minister of Labour how many women have been recruited in war industries since the outbreak of war; at what rate, approximately, they are now being engaged in these industries by week or month; and when the million women who it is estimated will be wanted, are likely to be absorbed in war industries?
I am not in a position to give the figures asked for by my hon. Friend.

publicwhip.major-heading: Oral Answers to Questions — NEW FACTORIES (LABOUR SUPPLY).

speech.p: asked the Minister of Labour whether he is aware that the erection of new, and extension of existing, factories in the city of Coventry will involve the transference to that city of 40,000 additional workmen, which far exceeds the available housing accommodation and will create serious problems; and whether he will confer with other Government Departments concerned with a view to ensuring a distribution of such industries over parts of the country where there is still unemployment and where sites and other facilities are available?

I am aware of the position at Coventry, on which I recently received a deputation from representatives of the local engineering employers, and my Department is at present engaged in a survey of present and future labour requirements. The decision to place additional capacity in the area was taken in the light of technical considerations, and my consultations with the other Departments gives me no reason to think that the arrangements already made can be altered. As the hon. Member knows, the possibilities of the areas to which he referred are always kept prominently before the Departments concerned.

Does not the right hon. Gentleman think it would be in the general interest if these works were distributed to those areas where there are available sites and housing accommodation rather than to districts where there is enormous congestion?
Subject to technical considerations, certainly, and I have done all that I can to secure that.

asked the Minister of Labour whether his attention has been called to the migration of labour from one factory or workshop to another in the Midland area; whether he realises the injurious effect of this state of affairs on the vitality of production for war purposes; and whether any steps can be taken to prevent shadow factories attracting men long before organised production can be undertaken?

As my hon. Friend knows, I am at present discussing with representatives of employers and workpeople in the engineering industry the general problem of labour supply in relation to the war effort. The provision of labour, including the essential nucleus of skilled labour, for new factories, is one of the subjects under examination.
When will my right hon. Friend be in a position to make a statement on the subject?
There is a number of highly difficult questions, and we are discussing these with practical men. As soon as we get their advice I shall be able to make a statement.
Can we have an assurance that no regulations will be introduced to bind men to certain factories?
Certainly.
Is the right hon. Gentleman aware of the migration of skilled labour from Scotland into England?
And that they never go back?

asked the President of the Board of Trade the number of factories opened in Durham, Northumberland, the North Riding of Yorkshire and the Greater London areas, respectively, during 1939; and the number of persons that have been placed in employment?

speech.speakername: The Parliamentary Secretary to the Board of Trade (Major Lloyd George)
speech.p: For reasons of economy, publication of particulars of industrial development has been suspended during the war.

Am I to understand that during the war the Government do not know how many factories are being set
up, where they are set up, or the number of people who are placed in employment?
The answer is that during the war publication has been suspended, and the information cannot be made available.
Where can we get that information? Has not this House the right to know where the factories are being set up and the number of people who are being placed in employment?
The reason is the question of economy, and as it involves a considerable number of staff to ensure publication, it has been suspended during the period of the war.
Where can we get the information? May I have an answer to my Question?
I cannot alter the answer that publication of these particulars has been suspended because of economy.
On a point of Order. I am not asking for publication, but for information on the matters set out in the Question.
The hon. Member will get the information if he asks the Minister.

publicwhip.major-heading: Oral Answers to Questions — CENTRAL REGISTER.

speech.p: asked the Minister of Labour the number of persons at present on the Central Register and on the two subsidiary registers which are maintained by the same staff; and the average weekly number of persons placed in employment from all three registers?

The number of persons enrolled on the Central Register on 29th February was 90,743 and on the two subsidiary registers 2,020 and 2,075 respectively. The average weekly number of persons notified as placed in employment from the Central Register between 16th October and 29th February is 192. As differing factors govern placing on the other two registers no combined average can be given, but I will send to my hon. Friend such particulars as are readily available.
Do I understand that it takes one person employed in these Departments a week to fix one person in employment?
No, I would not agree to that. An average may be a mathematical fact but a social and spiritual fiction.
Allowing for the hangover from last Saturday's performance, will my right hon. Friend say whether it takes 123 people a week to give employment to 192?
That is not so.

asked the Minister of Labour whether, in view of the public advertising by Government Departments for dieticians, he will consider the inclusion of such practical and professional workers in the Central Register?

I have not been able to trace any recent advertisements of this kind by Government Departments. I am not at present satisfied that any useful purpose would be served by enrolling dieticians on the Central Register.

Will the right hon. Gentleman reconsider this point in view of the training and experience of these people, not only in nutrition and food values, but in cooking, and could he ascertain from other Departments whether there has been some advertising for this particular class?
Perhaps the hon. Member will give me a clue to his Question, for I have not been able to trace it.

publicwhip.major-heading: Oral Answers to Questions — PORTS (SEAMEN'S WELFARE).

speech.p: asked the Minister of labour whether he is now able to make a statement on the subject of seamen's welfare in port?
I am in course of consultation with the Departments concerned and other interests on the subject of the method of co-ordinating action in respect of the various ports.
Can the right hon. Gentleman give me any idea when a conclusion will be reached?
We shall come to a conclusion as soon as we can. We are meeting representatives of the shipowners and the men.

Will the right hon. Gentleman see that buildings erected and
used for welfare purposes are not diverted to other purposes, such as sleeping accommodation for naval ratings?
I hope the hon. and learned Member will not prejudice the discussions. When I said "interests," I had all these things in mind.
Can the discussions be expedited?
We shall bring them to a satisfactory conclusion at the earliest possible date.

publicwhip.major-heading: Oral Answers to Questions — HOLIDAYS WITH PAY.

speech.p: asked the Minister of Labour the progress made in granting holidays with pay since the passage of the Holidays with Pay Act, in connection with trade boards and other wage-regulating authorities, and in voluntary industrial agreements generally?

Since the Holidays with Pay Act came into operation in July, 1938,Orders requiring employers to provide holidays with pay have been issued in respect of 49 trade boards, covering rather more than 1,000,000 people. In a further six cases notices of proposal to make such an Order have been issued. As regards Agricultural Wages Committees, I am informed that Orders have been issued in respect of all areas (with the exception of Monmouthshire) into which Great Britain is divided for the purpose of the Agricultural Wages Acts. These Orders cover about 600,000 workpeople. In addition, an Order relating to the road motor haulage industry has been issued by the Road Haulage Central Wages Board making holidays with pay for employés of "A" and "B" licence holders in Great Britain statutorily enforceable as from 29th January, 1940. It is estimated that the number of persons covered by collective agreements providing for holidays with pay is now about 4,500,000. This compares with an estimate of 3,000,000 made by the Amulree Committee when presenting their report in March, 1938.
Can my right hon. Friend say whether that very satisfactory progress is still being continued?

Certainly, Sir. The House took the view that the method of
collective agreements was the best way of dealing with the matter, and it has proved so.
Is the Minister aware that this Act has resulted in an increasing number of English people going to Scotland for their holidays, and staying there?

publicwhip.major-heading: Oral Answers to Questions — GOVERNMENT CONTRACTS (PUBLICATION OF LISTS).

speech.p: asked the Minister of Labour what arrangements he has now made to make available to interested parties the location of contracts placed by His Majesty's Government as a substitute for their publication in the "Labour Gazette"?
I am not yet able to add anything to the reply given to the hon. Member on 8th February.
Will the Minister try to expedite the decision?
We will do our best.

publicwhip.major-heading: Oral Answers to Questions — EDUCATION.

speech.p: asked the Parliamentary Secretary to the Board of Education whether, in view of the particular importance of first-aid in war-time, and in view of the fact that the subject is only one of many health matters dealt with in the recently-issued "Suggestions on Health Education," he will communicate with local education authorities suggesting that elementary first-aid should be taught to all children of an appropriate age?

speech.speakername: The Parliamentary Secretary to the Board of Education (Mr. Kenneth Lindsay)
speech.p: The "Suggestions on Health Education" in which reference was made to instruction in first-aid was published as recently as January last, and the Board do not consider it necessary to draw the further attention of local education authorities to the matter at present. I should prefer, in accordance with the usual practice, to leave it to their discretion and to that of the teachers in the schools.
In view of the importance of this first-aid training, will the Minister keep his eye on the progress made?
Yes, Sir, I will. It is not our practice to do more than make suggestions, but I hope what I have said will be brought to the attention of local authorities.

asked the Parliamentary Secretary to the Board of Education what steps the Board has taken or intends to take to ensure that children, particularly those evacuated, are not given moral instruction contrary to the principles held by their parents; and whether the Board will cause disciplinary action to be taken against teachers who offend in this respect?
I have no grounds for thinking that any such instruction is given in schools under the Board's jurisdiction.
May I ask my hon. Friend to answer my Question and say whether he proposes to give to parents of children who have been evacuated the right to see that they are educated according to their wishes?

I think I should read the answer again: I have no grounds for thinking that any-such instruction is given in schools under the Board's jurisdiction. I should add that if my hon. and gallant Friend has any specific cases to bring to my notice I shall be glad to look into them.
As the position stands, what rights have the parents got to see that their children who are evacuated are taught according to their wishes? Have they any rights?

I shall be sending my hon. and gallant Friend a copy of my answer. This is a serious charge, and I think he ought to give me specific examples before I can possibly say more in answer to his Question.
Is the Minister aware that while some evacuated children are, no doubt, subject to the influence of persons of Fascist opinions—[Interruption].

asked the Parliamentary Secretary to the Board of Education whether he is aware that a number of teachers with Marxist opinions are taking advantage of the evacuation
scheme and the consequent separation of children from their parents to inculcate principles contrary to Christian teaching and morality and to endeavour to destroy all respect the children have for their parents according to the tenets of Marxism; and what steps he proposes to take to prevent this?

The answer to the first part of the Question is in the negative; the second part does not therefore arise. Any specific case which my hon. and gallant Friend can adduce will, of course, be investigated.

In view of the fact that a responsible organisation is prepared to give him details of complaints in five different counties, will my hon. Friend undertake to look into them and, if he finds the complaints are substantiated, see that the wishes of the parents are respected and that the children are protected from such teaching, whether it be Fascist or Marxist?
Certainly, Sir. We are against any doctrinaire teaching in schools. If my hon. and gallant Friend will give me any specific cases, they will be investigated.
Has the hon. Member any reason to believe that the hon. and gallant Member who asks the Question is associated with any responsible organisation?

asked the Parliamentary Secretary to the Board of Education whether, in view of the disclosure that bad cooking and bad meal planning result in food wastage in Army units owing to an inadequate supply of capable cooks that might otherwise be drawn from civil life, he will take the initiative and make cooking and housekeeping a more important part of the education of children in all schools?

The training of cooks for His Majesty's Forces is not a matter falling within the Board's province. Cookery has, however, long been a regular subject in the general education of older girls in public elementary and secondary schools. There are also trade schools for girls and one for boys desiring vocational training in cookery, and some 80,000 older students attend day or
evening classes in the subject. The need for promoting the right use of food and preventing waste in its preparation was emphasised by the Board in a Circular dated 31st January, of which I am sending my hon. Friend a copy.

publicwhip.major-heading: Oral Answers to Questions — CIVIL DEFENCE.

speech.p: asked the Minister of Health whether, in deciding upon the number of children to be evacuated to reception areas in Wales under his new proposals, regard has been had to the household and school accommodation available in each reception area; and whether the consent of the local authorities was secured before the allocation was made?

The allocations to reception districts have been based on the returns of available household accommodation made by the local authorities themselves last year, and in Wales, as elsewhere, allowance has been made for accommodation which may already have been taken up as a result of private arrangements or otherwise. I am sending the hon. Member copies of a circular and memorandum which I have recently issued to the local authorities, from which he will see that provision is made for close collaboration between evacuating and receiving authorities and between billeting and education authorities with a view to ensuring, so far as possible, that the billeting and educational capacity of reception areas is used to the best advantage.
May I ask whether, if any local authority makes representations on the matter, the right hon. Gentleman will be prepared to reconsider them?
I am not prepared to do that this time.

asked the Minister of Health whether he will make arrangements, in conference with the Minister of Transport, by which parents, whose children are evacuated at a great distance from home, may, when using the cheap fares facilities, return home the following day?

The facilities already available permit the return journey to be made
the following day, where the distance between the evacuating and receiving area is such that the double journey cannot conveniently be made in one day after allowing a reasonable time to be spent in the receiving area.

Is the right hon. Gentleman aware that the children in my area are evacuated to Exeter and that, as many of the parents have more than one child, it is impossible under the present arrangements for the parents to see their children for more than a few minutes; and can he reconsider the situation and provide some solution?
My answer applies to Exeter.
To Exeter itself?

asked the Minister of Health whether he will make arrangements in conference with the Minister of Transport, whereby parents, whose children are evacuated at a great distance from home, and whose small incomes prevent them visiting their children, even taking into account the cheap fare facilities, might periodically have free travel vouchers granted to them?

As I said in reply to the hon. Member for West Leyton (Mr. Sorensen) on 22nd February, special assistance may be granted to parents in receipt of unemployment assistance who could not otherwise afford to visit their children, and I am proposing to empower local authorities to grant similar help to parents in receipt of public assistance. I do not think that any further action would be justified at the present time.

Is the Minister aware that the fare to Exeter is about 13s. 6d. and that the parents have to pay, further, bus fares; that mothers who have to rely upon dependant allowances find it impossible to visit their children; and that there are mothers who have not visited their children for six months?
No, Sir. The maximum fare is 12s. return.

Would the right hon. Gentleman not give further consideration to this matter, as, in point of fact, it costs many parents 14s. or 15s., with bus fares, to see their children? Is it not obvious
that a mother who is living on dependants' allowance cannot afford to pay that money to see her children?
I shall be glad to give consideration to any representations made to me by the hon. Gentleman.

asked the Minister of Health whether he will now give an assurance that, in the event of further evacuation of children taking place after the development of air attack, he will issue instructions that compulsory billeting shall not take place where the woman who would be responsible for the care of such children is genuinely engaged in agricultural work?

Local authorities have been directed to make sure, when allotting evacuated children to householders, that this is done in a way which will not interfere with the maintenance of the supply of agricultural labour. They may, I am sure, be relied on to give proper consideration to all cases in which the presence of evacuated children might hinder a housewife from undertaking her customary agricultural work.

asked the Minister of Health whether, in the next evacuation scheme, he will arrange that evacuated children are sent to reception areas in which are already billeted children from the same evacuable area; whether he will avoid, as far as possible, having many sets of teachers and children from different schools in one particular area; and whether he will arrange for children from Leyton and other urban Essex districts to go to the reception areas in rural Essex?

In making plans for further evacuation, we have had to take account of the results of the scheme carried out in September last. The effect of this scheme, particularly in the case of London, was to concentrate the great majority of the children evacuated in the more accessible reception areas, leaving the remoter areas comparatively little used. The bulk of the accommodation available for the new scheme is, therefore, to be found in the areas to which few children were sent last time, while the areas whose accommodation was heavily drawn upon then have less spare accommodation now. While I am in agreement with the hon. Member as to the value of the principles which he has in mind, the extent to which
it may be possible to observe them in practice must be limited by the factors to which I have already referred.

May I take it that the right hon. Gentleman will encourage as far as possible in any new evacuation scheme that children from districts such as Leyton shall go to places where there is suitable accommodation, seeing that numbers of the children previously sent away have already returned home?
Yes, Sir; and I think that if the hon. Gentleman will pursue the matter and come round and discuss it with my officials, we might be able to go into this case in more detail.
asked the Minister of Health whether, in respect of new evacuation proposals, he has further considered the question of assisting the evacuation of invalids and aged persons?

Yes. Sir, but, as I announced in reply to the right hon. Member for Wakefield (Mr. A. Greenwood) on 15th February, the new plans which have been made will apply to school children only, not to adults.
Can the right hon. Gentleman explain why they should not apply to adults as well, especially as numbers of these people are in great anxiety lest they be left in some vulnerable area?
The strain on billeting accommodation is already very great indeed, and I fear that we cannot add to the numbers of persons whom we intend to send out.
asked the Minister of Health whether he can furnish an approximate estimate of the cost, to the latest available date, of the evacuation of school children?

I regret that no reliable estimate of the total cost of the evacuation of school children can be given as particulars to be furnished by local authorities of the expenditure incurred by them on account of evacuation are still outstanding in a large number of cases. The main item of evacuation expenditure relates to billeting of which the estimated approximate gross cost to date is £7,000,000.

asked the Minister of Health whether any investigations are being made by his Department into the deleterious effect on the health of the people owing to lack of proper ventilation because of the black-out; and, if so, what is the result of this investigation?

Attention is being paid to the effect on the health of the people, of abnormal conditions created by the war, of which the black-out is one, but no special investigations of the nature suggested have been undertaken.
Will the right hon. Gentleman bear this aspect of the problem in mind, and is he aware that investigations have been made in some quarters which do show that health has been affected?
I shall be glad to consider any evidence which the hon. Member has.
Could not inspectors be sent round to open bedroom windows?

asked the Secretary of State for the Home Department whether his Department have conducted any experiments to secure better ventilation in houses, factories, offices and public buildings during the black-out, and, if so, with what results?

speech.speakername: The Secretary of State for the Home Department (Sir John Anderson)
speech.p: Yes, Sir. Experiments have been carried out by my Department, and it is proposed to issue shortly a pamphlet on Factory Ventilation in the Black-out, and specifications of means of ventilation suitable for houses, offices and public buildings.

Having regard to the fact that the Royal Air Force the other night were able to find the Unter den Linden in blacked-out Berlin, may I ask the right hon. Gentleman what advantage it is to have a black-out here?
That question has been dealt with effectively in Debate.
Does this apply to air-raid warden posts and so on, which are very badly ventilated in many cases?
Those have been attended to, for the most part.
What is the use of a black-out in the West of Scotland when there are iron works blazing up every night? Why cannot I have an answer to that question?

asked the Home Secretary whether he has considered a resolution from the education office of Bilston asking for a commission of inquiry into the question of the proportion of air-raid precautions costs that should be paid by the Home Office, and by local authorities, respectively; and what action he proposes to take?
I would refer my hon. Friend to the reply which I gave on 29th February to Questions by the hon. Members for Cheltenham (Mr. Lipson), Stratford (Mr. Groves) and West Leyton (Mr. Sorensen).

asked the Home Secretary whether he has considered the resolutions of the Essex Education Committee concerning inadequate grants for air-raid precautions in schools; how many similar representations he has received from local authorities; whether he is aware that the Essex County Council has to levy a rate of approximately 4½d. in the £ to meet air-raid precautions expenditure, largely to safeguard schools; and, in view of the increasing burden on Essex ratepayers and the disproportionate expenditure in respect of vulnerable eastern counties as compared with other counties, he will increase the percentage grant for school air-raid precautions and equalise the financial burden as between all counties?

I have received a copy of the resolutions passed by the Essex Education Committee and similar representations from some 120 other local education authorities. My attention has been drawn to a statement that the precept of the Essex County Council on the rating authorities for the coming financial year has been increased by 4d., but I have no knowledge how far this increase is attributable to the cost of protective work at schools. As regards the last part of the Question, I would refer the hon. Member to the answer which I gave him on 29th February last.

Does the right hon. Gentleman's answer mean that he is going to reconsider the matter or not? Is he aware that the whole of the Essex County Council feel very strongly indeed that a larger share of these burdens should be borne by the State rather than by the ratepayers?

I have already said that the matter would be considered on its merits, in connection with discussions that are about to take place with the Association of Local Authorities regarding the burden of Civil Defence costs.
When will those discussions take place?
I shall be communicating, I hope, with the Association of Local Authorities within the next few days.
asked the Home Secretary how many active burning pit-heaps there are in Northumberland; and what steps are being taken to extinguish them?

I am informed that, as a result of the measures taken to deal with the burning pit-heaps in the county of Northumberland no pit-heap in the county is now seriously on fire, though six are still liable to flare up on occasion.

Will the right hon. Gentleman make further inquiries into this matter, because whoever is responsible cannot have seen some of the burning pit-heaps recently? I can assure the right hon. Gentleman that some of them are showing a thousand lights in the darkness.

I should be very glad to have any information which the hon. Gentleman has in his possession. My information was quite recent. I am aware that 30 pit-heaps in the county of Northumberland are under continuous inspection, but, as I have said, they are liable to flare up from time to time.
Does that apply throughout the country?
Yes, Sir. Steps are taken throughout the country to deal with burning pit-heaps by methods which have been worked out during the past year.
asked the Home Secretary which scale of Civil Service expenses payments are given to the Civil and Assistant Civil Area Commissioners?

I assume that what the hon. Member desires is particulars of the Civil Service rates of expenses to which I referred in my answer to his Question on 7th March. The rates are those applicable to senior civil servants, and I am sending particulars to the hon. Member.
May I ask the right hon. Gentleman whether the expenses are taken by all the Commissioners, or are some of them not taken?
I think the House knows that some of the Commissioners are not drawing the salaries allowed by the Statute.
I was not asking about salaries. I was asking about expenses.

asked the Home Secretary whether he has considered resolutions of protest against the announcement of his intention to revoke the Order-in-Council of October last providing for the earlier closing of shops; and whether he proposes to take any action on the lines of the proposals of the shop assistants, warehousemen and clerks that their working hours should be reduced to 48 per week?

asked the Home Secretary whether, in view of the appeal made to the public by the Chancellor of the Exchequer to avoid all unnecessary spending, he will continue the regulation for the earlier closing of shops after 17th March, and so prevent people being tempted to buy goods; and whether he will extend the regulations to include confectioners, tobacconists and public-houses?

As I explained in the Debate on 24th January, and in reply to a Question by the hon. Member for Durham (Mr. Ritson) on 29th February, the regulation for the earlier closing of shops was made in view of the special conditions arising out of the black-out, and I am advised that there is no power to
continue it during the summer when day light lasts until 8 p.m. or later. The general question of the regulation of wages, hours and conditions of employment in the distributive trades is a separate matter which my right hon. Friend the Minister of Labour is considering in consultation with organisations representing employers and workpeople in those trades.
Does the right hon. Gentleman not realise that it is no use trade unions securing decent weekly hours for our men if at the same time the Government are encouraging later hours?
I think the hon. Lady must know that what is being asked for will require legislation, and I think it is pretty clear that such legislation would be acutely controversial.
Would it be in order for me now to ask my question regarding the black-out?
Not on these Questions.
May I ask if there is any demand from the general public that those regulations should be enforced?
As I have explained to the House on previous occasions, the point is that it would be ultra vires of the Emergency Powers Act to continue the regulations in force after the period of short days.
Is it not possible to issue an order under the Defence of the Realm Act for early closing, as was done in the last war?
What was done in the last war was to fix hours which are the hours provided for now under the ordinary law.

Does not this experiment show that people do not want to shop late, that the late hours have not been made use of, and in view of that fact, will the right hon. Gentleman consult with the Minister of Labour in order to get this legislation through?
That is another question altogether.

asked the Home Secretary what relaxation of the black-out restrictions will be permitted during the summer months for windows, skylights,
etc., in private houses, shops, factories and other premises; and, further, whether he will approve a type of light for use within buildings which would be of negligible assistance to aircraft although detectable at ground level?

The black-out remains an essential part of our defences, and I could not hold out any hope of relaxation of the restrictions applicable to the interior lighting of premises of all kinds. As regards the last part of the Question, I know of no satisfactory form of general interior lighting which is invisible from the air if windows are not obscured.
Is the Minister aware that we have a great ironworks in the heart of Glasgow and one just outside Glasgow which are blazing forth and lighting the heavens every night in the midst of the black-out?
It is recognised as a great disadvantage. Power was taken under the Civil Defence Act to deal with such cases, but they require structural alteration, and that takes time.
Will the right hon. Gentleman carry out that Act in regard to this case? I can see the light when I am miles away outside Glasgow.

Does the right hon. Gentleman realise that in certain parts of Scotland although the black-out on the land is effective, there seems to be no regulation governing the ships in the harbours? I can give some instances where it is quite absurd to black-out places and have the ships all lit up.
That is a matter for another authority.

asked the Home Secretary whether he is aware that a further death by drowning has taken place at Greenock Harbour, bringing the total during the black-out to 21; that, beyond modified lighting, no further steps have been taken to secure the safety of those whose duties require their attendance at the harbour during the hours of the black-out; that this state of matters is continuing to cause dissatisfaction; and what further steps he proposes to take to eliminate this black-out menace?

I am informed by the chief constable that there have been no deaths from drowning in Greenock Harbour since I answered the hon. Member's Question on 22nd February. A body has since then been recovered from the harbour, but it appeared to have been in the water for some weeks. Fencing has already been erected to keep unauthorised persons away from the harbour premises, and I understand that the local naval authorities and the harbour authority are considering the question of erecting further safety barriers inside the harbour. I will bring the hon. Member's representations to the notice of my right hon. Friends, the First Lord of the Admiralty and the Minister of Transport.

Is the right hon. Gentleman aware that all responsible authorities in Greenock consider the position extremely serious, and that since this Question was put on the Order Paper two men have fallen 20 feet into a motor boat at the East India Dock in the dark—I received that news this morning; and is he also aware that every civic representative in Greenock considers that the whole of the docks should be—
The hon. and learned Member must not make a statement. He had better send it to the Minister.

asked the Home Secretary whether he is aware that an auxiliary fireman was fined £20 at a London police court, on the 8th instant, for exceeding 20 miles per hour when driving an Auxiliary Fire Service car; and, in view of the fact that the man's weekly wage is £2 18s. 5d. per week, that prior to this offence he had a good driving record, and that driving a fire brigade car was an extra and unpaid duty for which he volunteered, will he review the circumstances with special regard to the means of the defendant?
I am having inquiry made about this case, and am not in a position at present to make any statement.

Will my right hon. Friend tell the magistrates why this particular regulation, for a 20 miles speed limit in the black-out, was brought in under the Defence of the Realm Act, because misunderstanding is arising?
Is the right hon. Gentleman not aware that, in fact, this penalty is 20 times larger than penalties for similar offences under the ordinary law?
I think it better that I should not offer any comment without due deliberation with the magistrates concerned.

asked the Home Secretary how many prosecutions and convictions there have been for exceeding the 20-mile speed limit during the black-out in the Metropolitan Police District since the limit was imposed on 1st February?

I regret that the information asked for is not yet available. If my hon. Friend will put his Question down again some time after the end of this month, I hope I may be able to give him the information for which he asks.
Is my right hon. Friend aware that the Metropolitan Police are trying to tail cars, and that, with the present mask, they cannot possibly see more than feet at 19 paces ahead of them in the dark?
I think that Question had better be put down.

asked the Home Secretary the reason for the absence from duty of the Regional Commissioner for the Yorkshire area, and what arrangements have been made for the carrying out of his duties in his absence?

The Regional Commissioner for the North-Eastern region recently undertook a lecture tour in Portugal, at the request of the British Council and with my assent. The tour involved an absence of three weeks and the Commissioner is now back on duty. During his absence his duties as Commissioner were discharged by the Deputy-Commissioner.

asked the Home Secretary how many Anderson shelters have been delivered but not erected; and whether, in districts where large numbers of shelters are lying rusting where they were delivered, he will either urge the local authorities to have these erected without further delay or have them salvaged in order that this
valuable scrap may be put to some useful purpose?

I have no precise and up-to-date figures, but the matter has been the subject of inquiry from time to time, and I am satisfied that, taking the country as a whole, the number of shelters not yet erected represents only a small proportion of the total number distributed. I am aware, however, that the position is not so satisfactory in certain areas, where the local authorities have not exercised their statutory powers to erect the shelters themselves but have left the matter to the householders, and I am arranging for special measures to be taken to remedy the situation in those areas.
What measures is my right hon. Friend taking?
I will send my hon. and gallant Friend a copy of the instructions.

publicwhip.major-heading: Oral Answers to Questions — KITCHEN WASTE (COLLECTION).

speech.p: asked the Minister of Health whether apparatus acquired or to be acquired for boiling or reducing kitchen waste suitable for feeding livestock, collected by local authorities, can rank for grant or for loan purposes?

I am prepared to consider, in consultation with my right hon. Friend the Minister of Supply, applications by local authorities for consent to borrow money for the installation of any necessary plant for the purpose indicated. Such plant would be revenue-producing; there is no Government grant available in connection with the expenditure.
Would the right hon. Gentleman let the local authorities know that he is prepared to consider this matter?
I hope that this Question and answer will draw their attention to the point.

publicwhip.major-heading: Oral Answers to Questions — SHIPWRECKED PERSONS (ASSISTANCE).

speech.p:
asked the Minister of Health whether he has sent or will send a circular to local authorities of port towns informing them that the
responsibility for seeing that such necessities as clothing, food, and shelter for shipwrecked persons are the responsibility of county or county borough councils, and that in nearly all cases expenditure of local authorities so incurred will be recoverable out of public funds?
Yes, Sir, I issued a circular on 29th February on the lines indicated in the Question. I am sending my hon. and gallant Friend a copy.
Why should this be done locally and not by the Government?
I am afraid that that is another question.

publicwhip.major-heading: Oral Answers to Questions — OLD AGE PENSIONS.

speech.p: asked the Minister of Health whether he is aware that Mr. E. Simpson, of 179, Queen's Road, Plaistow, E.13, an old age pensioner, pension book No. 09434141, has been without his new pension book for three weeks on Thursday last; that the yellow note form for a new pension book was sent on 10th December; whether he is aware that several letters have been sent to Blackpool, including one from the hon. Member for the division; and whether he can say what action he intends taking about the delay?

Mr. Simpson removed to Ospringe, Kent, in September last and asked that his pension might be made payable there. On 26th February, 1940, a letter was received from him from his London address stating that his new pension order book, current from 22nd February, had not arrived. This new book had, unfortunately, already been sent to Ospringe. Steps were at once taken to recall it, and on 6th March Mr. Simpson was notified that a new book had been sent to the post office at Plaistow.
The matter has been rectified, but I hope that the Minister will correct any other such cases.
I think the difficulty arose in this case out of a wrong address having been given.

asked the Minister of Health how soon he expects the application forms for supplementary pensions to be available; and whether they will
be obtainable at the post offices as well as at the offices of the Board?

I am not yet in a position to give the date when application forms for supplementary pensions will be available, but the hon. Member may be assured that they will be provided in ample time before the date from which the supplementary pensions become payable. The answer to the second part of the Question is "Yes."

publicwhip.major-heading: Oral Answers to Questions — RATING (SMALL SHOPKEEPERS).

speech.p: asked the Minister of Health whether, in view of the increased burdens upon the smaller shopkeepers and ratepayers, he will consider the introduction of some amending legislation to review the incidence of rateability and to remove certain apparent anomalies arising through the concessions of derating?
I am not in a position to add to the answer given to my hon. and gallant Friend the Member for East Willesden (Captain Hammersley) on 29th February.
Does my right hon. Friend realise that the benefits of derating are going to many very prosperous firms while small shopkeepers and little tradesmen are called upon to bear an ever-rising burden?

publicwhip.major-heading: Oral Answers to Questions — BUILDING SOCIETIES (INTEREST RATES).

speech.p: asked the Prime Minister whether he will find time to debate the Motion standing in the name of the hon. Member for Evesham, relating to Building Societies (Interest Rates)?

[That this House strongly disapproves the action of certain building societies in increasing the rates of mortgage interest on existing mortgages by the half of 1 per cent., having regard to the effect of such action on interest rates generally, the reduction in saving thereby effected, and the obvious hardship on hard-pressed mortgagors.]
I regret that I can hold out no hope of special facilities being given for discussion of the Motion standing in the name of my hon. Friend.

Does my right hon. Friend not realise that there is no justification for building societies endeavouring to take advantage of small traders, and does he not think it is indefensible and really brings the whole building society movement into disrepute?

publicwhip.major-heading: Oral Answers to Questions — HOUSING (REPAIRS).

speech.p: asked the Minister of Health whether he will consider advising local authorities, especially in view of the difficulty experienced by many people in paying both rent and rates, to postpone or not to insist until after the war on all work on existing houses which is not absolutely necessary, such as the enforcement of separate communication water pipes instead of joint pipes which are now in perfect order, serving such houses to the satisfaction of the tenants?

I believe that local authorities, in the exercise of their powers in respect of existing houses, are in general taking into account the special circumstances arising from the war, and I doubt whether it is necessary or desirable for me at present to take the course suggested by my hon. Friend.

publicwhip.major-heading: Oral Answers to Questions — MEDICAL BENEFIT (ARMED FORCES' DEPENDANTS).

speech.p: asked the Minister of Health whether, during the present national emergency, when the National Health Insurance Fund is relieved of the liability to provide medical benefits for men with the Forces, he will consider providing such benefits to the dependants of these men?Mr. Elliot: I would refer the hon. Member to the reply which I gave on 22nd February to a similar Question by the hon. Member for Normanton (Mr. T. Smith).

In view of the very great hardships imposed upon people who have to depend upon public assistance, can the right hon. Gentleman not reconsider that decision; and, as he is saving money on one hand, can he not spend some of it on the other?
I pointed out in my answer that we are not saving money on the one hand, and therefore there is no margin available on the other.

publicwhip.major-heading: Oral Answers to Questions — ARMED FORCES (CIVIL MARRIAGE LICENCES).

speech.p: asked the Minister of Health whether he is aware that the Essex War Emergency Committee have authorised a reduction to 10s. in the total fee in respect of the marriage of a member of His Majesty's Forces below commissioned rank; and whether he will recommend this example to the authorities in other counties and in county boroughs?

Circulars have recently been addressed by the Registrar-General to county and county borough councils inviting them to authorise a reduction in suitable cases of the fees for the civil marriage by licence of members of His Majesty's Forces below commissioned rank, where the fees are receivable by salaried registration officers on behalf of the council. A corresponding reduction has been suggested by the Registrar-General to registration officers who are directly remunerated by fees. On the evidence so far available both councils and registration officers are responding readily to these proposals.

publicwhip.major-heading: Oral Answers to Questions — REFUGEES (NEW BUSINESSES).

speech.p: asked the Home Secretary whether he is now able to state the number and extent of the new undertakings and the amount of trade and employment created as a result of factories and businesses started by refugees in this country?

Compilation of information on this subject is in progress with a view to the publication of the comprehensive statement to which I referred in my reply to the hon. Member on 22nd February, but the inquiries are not yet completed.
Can the right hon. Gentleman say how soon he expects to be able to publish it?
Not for at least a month yet.

publicwhip.major-heading: Oral Answers to Questions — SHIPYARDS (ACCIDENTS).

speech.p: asked the Home Secretary the number of fatal and other accidents in British shipyards for each month from October, 1939, to February last, inclusive?
As the answer involves a number of figures, I will, with the hon. Member's permission, circulate it in the OFFICIAL REPORT.
Following are the figures:

publicwhip.major-heading: Oral Answers to Questions — CINEMAS (SUNDAY OPENING).

speech.p: asked the Home Secretary whether he will take steps to ensure that cinema performances are provided on Sundays in all districts where there are substantial concentrations of troops; and whether he will obtain the necessary power, by legislation or regulation, to override local authorities which have banned Sunday cinema shows?
No, Sir. As at present advised, I could not recommend that power should be taken to override local opinion in this matter as suggested by my hon. Friend.

Does not the Minister think it absurd that the troops should have to go and fight on Sundays and concerts are allowed for them on Sundays, but that in some parts of the country cinemas have not been allowed to open because of the fuss that has been made by some of the people in the localities?
Would the right hon. Gentleman also remember that overseas troops wander around the streets with nothing at all to do on Sundays?

I think the House is aware that a regulation was recently made providing for a greatly simplified procedure for regulating the Sunday opening of cinemas. My information is that good use is being made of that procedure, and about 30 Orders have already reached the Home Office.
Will the right hon. Gentleman be good enough to give this matter further consideration?

publicwhip.major-heading: Oral Answers to Questions — PEACE PLEDGE UNION.

speech.p: asked the Home Secretary whether he is aware that there is much indignation in the Midlands at the activities of the Peace Pledge Union in its efforts to encourage and tutor men in their applications for exemption from military service on the grounds of conscientious objection; and at the distribution of handbills and literature likely to be detrimental to the Defence of the Realm; and what steps he proposes to take to end this subversive action?

asked the Home Secretary whether he is aware that certain persons in Birmingham and the Midlands have organised a system of picketing at recruiting offices and Employment Exchanges offering to provide advice for recruits who desire to evade military service and to assist them in presenting their appeals to War Office tribunals in order to secure their release from service; and what action he contemplates to prevent the continuance of this effort against the organisation of national defence?

asked the Home Secretary whether he has further considered the subversive activities of the Peace Pledge Union who, besides distributing literature detrimental to the country's interest, are picketing recruiting offices; and whether he will take steps to stop this interference with the liberties of patriotic Britishers?

There is, I think, no reason for apprehension that these activities have any appreciable effect on the organisation of national defence or on the determination of the British people to devote themselves to the efficient prosecution of the war. As previously stated, however, I am having a close watch kept, and am keeping in view the question whether special measures may be called for.
Does my right hon. Friend not realise that these busybodies who are trying to encourage men to evade military service are a positive danger to the country?
Reports reaching me from every quarter go to show that the activities referred to are, in fact, having no serious effect, beyond making a certain number of people very angry.

Is not any individual belonging to an anti-war organisation entitled to give out leaflets at Employment Exchanges, showing individuals the rights they have under the Act? Is it not the case that we have had to raise a number of C.O. claims by men who did not know their rights? Is there anything criminal or wrong in doing that?
A great deal depends on how it is done.

publicwhip.major-heading: Oral Answers to Questions — GREAT BRITAIN AND CHANNEL ISLANDS (TRAVEL RESTRICTIONS).

speech.p: asked the Home Secretary whether he is prepared to relax the restrictions on travel between Great Britain and the Channel Islands?

Yes, Sir. I have come to the conclusion that it is not necessary to maintain control over this traffic in present circumstances. Accordingly, persons wishing to go to the Channel Islands will require neither exit permits, nor pass ports, nor travel permit cards in lieu of passports.

publicwhip.major-heading: Oral Answers to Questions — WEST INDIES (TAXATION).

speech.p: asked the Chancellor of the Exchequer whether he is aware of the difference in Income Tax, and other taxation, between sugar and similar firms established in this country and firms carrying out the same activities in the West Indies; and whether he will take steps to avoid such disparity in order to restrict the drift of capital from this country to the West Indies, whereby the Budget in this country would only be able to include a tax on the revenue from dividends instead of a tax on profits?

speech.speakername: The Chancellor of the Exchequer (Sir John Simon)
speech.p: I am aware of the difference between the rates of direct taxation in the West Indian Colonies and in the United Kingdom, but I have no evidence that the disparity is causing a drift of capital from this country to the West Indies. As regards taxation in the West Indian Colonies, I would refer my hon. Friend to the answer given by the Secretary of State for the Colonies to a Question by the hon. Member for the Clayton Division of Manchester (Mr. Jagger) on 13th March.

publicwhip.major-heading: Oral Answers to Questions — GOVERNMENT DEPARTMENTS (WAR DIARIES).

speech.p: asked the Financial Secretary to the Treasury whether all Departments of State started a war diary on the outbreak of war; and whether such diaries are still being kept?

speech.speakername: The Financial Secretary to the Treasury (Captain Crookshank)
speech.p: At the outbreak of war it was arranged that all Departments of State should make collections of the material which will be required for writing a history of the war. In the case of Departments most directly concerned with the conduct of the war, war diaries are being kept.
Are war diaries being kept by all Departments?
I said that they were being kept by those most directly concerned with the conduct of the war.

publicwhip.major-heading: Oral Answers to Questions — SPECIAL AREAS (FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE).

speech.p: asked the Financial Secretary to the Treasury whether, in the case of firms established with the financial assistance of the Special Areas Reconstruction Association, whose businesses are now in difficulties owing to war conditions, additional financial help will be made available to them?

Applications for additional financial help from businesses in difficulties owing to war conditions will be carefully considered by the Special Areas Reconstruction Association, in the light of all the relevant circumstances.

publicwhip.major-heading: Oral Answers to Questions — BUILDING SOCIETIES (MORTGAGE INTEREST).

speech.p: asked the Financial Secretary to the Treasury whether he is aware that the Bradford Permanent Building Society is calling in the mortgages granted to owner-occupiers in order to increase the rate of interest, thereby creating great hardship; and, since these contracts were completed before the country became involved in war, will he take steps to override this action?

I would refer my hon. Friend to the answer I gave on 27th
February to my hon. Friend the Member for the Moseley Division (Sir P. Hannon).
Would my right hon. and gallant Friend make some suggestion to this society, in the kindliest and gentlest way, that it should not press these poor people in this way?

Is my right hon. and gallant Friend aware of the great distress being caused to a number of working-class families who are buying their houses, by this action, which can only be described as force majeure?

publicwhip.major-heading: Oral Answers to Questions — CIVIL SERVICE EXAMINATIONS.

speech.p: asked the Financial Secretary to the Treasury whether he is aware that the Institute of Bankers, which last year arranged examinations for more than 14,000 bank clerks throughout Great Britain, has decided that war-time conditions shall not prevent the examinations from being held this year; and whether he will ascertain whether their arrangements to this end can be copied by the Civil Service Commission in the case of Civil Service examinations?

The examination to which the hon. Member refers is, I understand, an examination of a qualifying character open to members of the Institute of Bankers. I do not consider that there is any real analogy between an examination of such a character and the open competitive examinations held by the Civil Service Commissioners.
Does the right hon. and gallant Gentleman say that to examine 14,000 candidates in banking is a less difficult task than examining candidates for the Civil Service?
The hon. Gentleman, I think, missed the point of the adjectives I used. One was "qualifying" and the other "competitive."
Teach them social credit.
I may be very dull, but would the right hon. and gallant Gentleman tell me what is the difficulty in organising one kind of examination as compared with the other?
Yes, Sir. If the hon. Gentleman likes to put down a question, I will give him a full reply.

publicwhip.major-heading: Oral Answers to Questions — AGRICULTURE (HEAVY HORSES).

speech.p: asked the Minister of Agriculture whether he is aware that, despite the assistance to farmers in the provision of tractors, the high prices of fuel, together with special circumstances on certain farms, make it essential to retain a certain number of heavy horses for general utility work; and whether he will reconsider the policy of withdrawing entirely the financial support hitherto given to the breeding of heavy agricultural horses?

speech.speakername: The Under-Secretary of State for Scotland (Captain McEwen)
speech.p: I have been asked to reply. My right hon. Friend is aware of the desirability of maintaining the supply of heavy horses, but he is not prepared to accept the implication in the latter part of the Question that in the absence of financial support breeding operations will be substantially curtailed. In any event, breeding in this and subsequent seasons is not likely to have any effect upon supplies of agricultural horses available during the war. My right hon. Friend has given very careful consideration to representations urging a resumption of the grants for heavy horse breeding but he regrets that he cannot see his way to withdraw the suspension.

publicwhip.major-heading: Oral Answers to Questions — TRADE STATISTICS (PUBLICATION).

speech.p: asked the President of the Board of Trade whether, as it is possible for Germany to deduce with considerable accuracy the volume of our trade in various commodities by an examination of the trade statistics of neutral countries, he will consider the resumption of the publication of fuller details in the monthly returns?

Though some countries continue to publish detailed monthly trade statistics, the information thus available would enable Germany to obtain only a partial record of our trade and that after a considerable interval. I fear therefore that the adoption of my hon. Friend's suggestion would be of assistance to the enemy.

Does not my hon. and gallant Friend think that this suppression of information is far more a suspension of our opportunites to consider the economic situation of this country than any protection against Germany?

publicwhip.major-heading: Oral Answers to Questions — SWEDISH IRON ORE (GERMAN IMPORTS).

speech.p: asked the Minister of Economic Warfare what quantities of iron ore have been shipped from Sweden to Germany through Norwegian territorial waters during the last three months?

speech.speakername: The Minister of Economic Warfare (Mr. Cross)
speech.p: I regret that in the absence of any published statistics I cannot give the information for which my hon. Friend asks.
Does my hon. Friend think that 500,000 tons a month would be an exaggeration?
Is it not time to put an end to the feeding of the enemy?

publicwhip.major-heading: Oral Answers to Questions — PIGS (EAR-MARKING).

speech.p: asked the Minister of Food whether his attention has been called to the fact that his Department has directed the cruel practice of punching holes in the ears of live pigs in connection with the Government's grading scheme; and will he see that any such order is cancelled forthwith?

speech.speakername: The Chancellor of the Duchy of Lancaster (Mr. W. S. Morrison)
speech.p: The ear-marking of pigs has been very carefully investigated by responsible officers in my Department, and I am satisfied that, whilst the practice is not painless, the pain inflicted is only momentary and causes no undue or sustained distress to the animal. I do not accept the view that the practice is cruel and I am not at present prepared to cancel the order which is essential for identification of the pig at the slaughterhouse.

Is my right hon. Friend aware of the horrible scenes that have occurred in many markets owing to this practice; and is he also aware that the grading of sheep has been arranged
and accomplished with great accuracy without any pain of this kind being caused to the animals?
The suggestion of my hon. Friend would involve a change in the grading of pigs from a dead-weight to a live-weight basis, and that would raise very important considerations.
Is the Minister aware that women have their ears pierced in order to put in ear-rings?

publicwhip.major-heading: Oral Answers to Questions — SIR MICHAEL O'DWYER (ASSASSINATION).

speech.p: (by Private Notice) asked the Prime Minister whether he has any statement to make about the assassination of Sir Michael O'Dwyer and the wounding of Lord Zetland and other distinguished persons at the Caxton Hall yesterday afternoon?

The House will be aware from the reports which have appeared in the Press that at the conclusion of a meeting held yesterday afternoon at the Caxton Hall under the auspices of the East India Association and the Royal Central Asian Society several shots were fired by a man in the audience, with the result that Sir Michael O'Dwyer was killed and the Secretary of State for India, Lord Lamington and Sir Louis Dane were wounded. An Indian named Udham Singh who is believed to have been responsible for the outrage was seized by members of the audience and handed over to the police, and he has this morning been brought before the magistrate at Bow Street Police Court on a charge of murder. In these circumstances it would not be proper for me to make any comment on the facts of the case.
I know, however, that the House will wish to join with me in expressing our deep sense of sympathy with Lady O'Dwyer and her family in the sudden and tragic loss which they have suffered. The House will also desire to extend to those who were wounded their good wishes for a rapid recovery. I understand that their injuries, happily, were not grave, and that all are making satisfactory progress.
Is it not the fact that this abominable outrage will be as keenly resented by all the people of India as by the people of this country?
I am sure that that is so.
Is the Prime Minister satisfied that adequate protection is given to the Secretary of State for India and other officials when attending meetings of this kind?
I do not think that it is possible to anticipate these occurrences.
I mean, of course, protection from fanatics as well.
Has the attention of the Prime Minister been called to the very gallant conduct of an English lady last night in connection with this matter?

publicwhip.major-heading: BUSINESS OF THE HOUSE.

speech.p: May I ask the Prime Minister to state the business of the House for next week?
Monday—Second Reading of the Consolidated Fund Bill; Debate on Shipping.
Tuesday—Committee and remaining stages of the Consolidated Fund Bill. I shall make a statement on the Progress of the War.

Wednesday—Consideration of Lords Amendments to the Old Age and Widows' Pensions Bill, and to the Agriculture (Miscellaneous War Provisions) Bill; Second Reading of the Societies (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill; Special Enactments (Extension of Time) Bill [Lords]; and, if there is time, of the Solicitors (Emergency Provisions) Bill [Lords].
Thursday—The House will meet at 11 a.m., and Questions will be taken. Motion for the Easter Adjournment until Tuesday, 2nd April.

We expect to receive the Lords Amendments to the Old Age Pensions Bill on Tuesday, but in the event of their not coming down until Wednesday, it will be necessary for them to be considered on Thursday.
We intend to put down a Motion on the Paper with regard to the shipping position for Monday's Debate.
Can my right hon. Friend state the date when the Budget will be introduced?
No, Sir.
